title: Cohere hits $7B valuation a month after its last raise, partners with AMD
author: TechCrunch
essence: News Summary: Cohere, an enterprise AI company, secured an additional $100 million in funding, increasing its valuation to $7 billion and announcing a partnership with AMD for its AI models to run on AMD's GPUs. Novelty/Claim to Fame: Cohere differentiates itself by focusing on the enterprise market, emphasizing AI sovereignty and data control, while partnering with AMD, a competitor to Nvidia, which backs OpenAI. Evidence: Cohere's valuation increased from $6.8 billion (August 2024) to $7 billion (October 2024) after a $100 million funding extension.
reactions: Cohere's $7 billion valuation, while impressive, pales in comparison to competitors OpenAI and Anthropic, highlighting the intense competition in the generative AI market.
Cohere's partnership with AMD, a competitor to Nvidia, could signal a shift in the industry's reliance on specific hardware providers, potentially fostering greater diversity in AI infrastructure.
Enterprises prioritizing data sovereignty may find Cohere's focus on on-premise solutions and its partnerships with investors from various regions (Canada, Mexico, Iberia) particularly attractive.

title: First migrants arrive in UK from France under 'one in one out' deal
author: BBC Top Stories
essence: News Summary: A family of three is the first to arrive in the UK from France under a new "one in, one out" migrant exchange deal, following the removal of four other migrants from the UK to France. Novelty/Claim to Fame: The agreement represents a new approach to managing cross-Channel migration, aiming to deter illegal crossings by exchanging returned migrants for refugees who haven't attempted the Channel crossing. Evidence/Uncertainty: The deal, announced in July by Prime Ministers Starmer and Macron, has seen four migrants removed from the UK (one Indian, one Eritrean, one Iranian, and one Afghan national) by September 23rd.
reactions: ) World Impact: The "one in, one out" deal, while a small-scale pilot, represents a potential shift in international cooperation on managing irregular migration across the English Channel, though its long-term effectiveness remains uncertain.

) What could change next:  The deal's success hinges on the scale of implementation; if significantly more migrants are returned to France, it could influence other European countries to adopt similar bilateral agreements.
) Practical implication for readers: The ongoing debate highlights the complex interplay between national sovereignty, humanitarian concerns, and the challenges of deterring illegal migration.

title: Creating a map of every living thing, cell by cell
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: A new initiative, the Biodiversity Cell Atlas, aims to create a comprehensive map of every eukaryotic cell on Earth, leveraging single-cell gene expression analysis to understand cellular diversity and its evolutionary context. Novelty/Claim to Fame: This project represents a significant expansion beyond genome sequencing, aiming to map cellular diversity across the entire eukaryotic tree of life at single-cell resolution. Evidence/Uncertainty: The initiative is spearheaded by the Wellcome Sanger Institute and the Center for Genomic Regulation (CRG), with a Nature publication (DOI: 10.1038/s41586-025-09312-4, September 2025) outlining the project's first phase.
reactions: ) World Impact:  The Biodiversity Cell Atlas, a global initiative, aims to revolutionize our understanding of life's evolution and cellular diversity, potentially impacting fields ranging from medicine and conservation to industrial applications, as stated by Dr. Arnau Sebé Pedrós.

) What could change next (speculation):  Building upon the success of genome sequencing projects like the Darwin Tree of Life, the standardization of single-cell analysis protocols in the BCA could lead to rapid advancements in comparative biology and the discovery of novel biological mechanisms.

) Practical implication for readers:  This project highlights the power of large-scale, collaborative scientific endeavors and emphasizes the importance of interdisciplinary cooperation for tackling complex global challenges, as underscored by the project's emphasis on collaboration across expertise and geographic location.

title: Scientists use electrons to pattern light sources and wiring directly onto crystals
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: Rice University scientists developed a method using a focused electron beam to directly pattern light sources and conductive wiring onto ultrathin molybdenum oxide crystals with submicron precision. Novelty: This one-step process creates nanoscale patterns of both light emission and electrical conductivity simultaneously, eliminating the need for multiple fabrication steps used in traditional lithography. Evidence: The research, published in Nano Letters (DOI: 10.1021/acs.nanolett.5c03617) in September 2025, by Hae Yeon Lee and Yifeng Liu, demonstrates patterns narrower than a DNA helix.
reactions: This electron-beam patterning technique allows for the creation of submicron-scale light sources and wiring directly onto crystals, potentially revolutionizing the manufacturing of compact optoelectronic devices.
Future applications may extend this method to other van der Waals materials, enabling the fabrication of more complex and integrated nanoscale devices with novel functionalities.
The development of this precise, one-step patterning method could significantly reduce the complexity and cost of manufacturing next-generation optoelectronic devices.

title: Around one in three hospital infections involve antimicrobial resistance, study shows
author: Medical Xpress – Health
essence: News Summary: A University of Leicester study found that approximately one-third of hospital-acquired infections globally involve antimicrobial resistance (AMR), significantly increasing patient mortality risk. Novelty/Claim to Fame: The study provides a global overview of AMR's prevalence in hospital infections and its association with increased mortality, highlighting significant data gaps in under-represented regions. Evidence: The meta-analysis of 34 studies (20,658 patients across 18 countries) published in eClinicalMedicine (September 2025) revealed a 36.5% prevalence of AMR in hospital infections.
reactions: The study reveals a concerningly high prevalence of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in hospital-acquired infections, with over one-third of cases involving drug-resistant bacteria and a 58% increased risk of death for affected patients.

Future research should prioritize expanding surveillance and studies in under-represented regions like parts of Africa, the Middle East, and South Asia to better understand the global burden of AMR and inform effective interventions.
Readers should advocate for improved infection control practices in healthcare settings and support initiatives aimed at promoting responsible antibiotic use to mitigate the growing threat of AMR.

title: NASA Data Powers New Tool to Protect Water Supply After Fires
author: NASA Breaking News
essence: News Summary: NASA's new online tool, HydroFlame, uses satellite data and AI to predict wildfire impacts on water resources, initially piloted in Montana's Clark Fork Basin and expanding to California and Utah. Novelty: HydroFlame uniquely integrates historical fire data, future scenario simulations, and near-real-time predictions to forecast wildfire's effects on water quality and flow, considering compounding factors like pre-fire drought. Evidence: The tool uses data from MODIS, Landsat, and SMAP satellites; a pilot program exists in Montana's Clark Fork Basin; a successful, albeit informal, real-time prediction of mudflows in Los Angeles County following the January 2025 Eaton Fire was achieved.
reactions: HydroFlame, a new NASA-supported tool using satellite data and AI, promises to significantly improve prediction of wildfire impacts on water resources, enabling proactive mitigation of subsequent mudslides, flooding, and water contamination as stated by Erin Urquhart, program manager for NASA’s water resources program.

Future development of HydroFlame may include expansion to more regions, integration of additional data sources (e.g., more ground sensors), and enhanced user interfaces to better serve diverse stakeholders,  potentially leading to more sophisticated early warning systems.

Water resource managers and city planners can utilize HydroFlame's "what-if" scenario builder to proactively assess wildfire risks to their specific water supplies, facilitating better preparedness and resource allocation, as highlighted by Kelly Luis, associate program manager for NASA’s water resources program.

title: Microbiologists develop bespoke phage therapy to combat antimicrobial resistance
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: Monash University researchers developed Entelli-02, a five-phage cocktail for treating antimicrobial-resistant Enterobacter cloacae complex (ECC) infections, a clinical-ready product now available for compassionate use. Novelty: This represents the first clinical-ready phage therapy product designed specifically for a hospital setting to combat a particular antimicrobial-resistant bacteria. Evidence: The study, published in Nature Microbiology (September 2025, DOI: 10.1038/s41564-025-02130-4), involved a decade of research, culminating in a five-phage cocktail (Entelli-02) that reduced bacterial loads in infected mice by over 99%.
reactions: World Impact: The development of Entelli-02, a five-phage cocktail targeting drug-resistant Enterobacter cloacae complex, offers a potential solution to the growing global threat of antimicrobial resistance, as evidenced by its effectiveness in reducing bacterial loads in mice by over 99%.

What could change next:  Further research and clinical trials could lead to the widespread adoption of this hospital-specific phage cocktail model, potentially replicating the success of Entelli-02 in other hospitals facing similar AMR threats and paving the way for personalized phage therapies.

Practical implication for readers: This research demonstrates the feasibility of creating and deploying targeted phage therapies to combat antimicrobial-resistant infections, offering a promising new avenue for treating currently intractable bacterial infections.

reactions: ) World Impact:  The study reveals a widening global distribution of Vibrio vulnificus, driven by warming waters, posing an increasing threat of infection, particularly in higher latitudes.

) What could change next (speculation):  Improved data collection and standardized infection reporting, coupled with further model refinement, could lead to more accurate predictions and targeted preventative measures in high-risk areas.

title: A Former Apple Luminary Sets Out to Create the Ultimate GPU Software
author: WIRED
essence: News Summary: Modular, a startup founded by former Apple and Google engineer Chris Lattner, secured $250 million in Series C funding to develop a unified software layer for AI chips, aiming to simplify cross-platform AI application development. reactions: Modular's goal is to create a unified software layer for AI chips, addressing the current fragmentation and dependence on a few dominant companies like Nvidia and AMD, aiming for "sovereign AI" across diverse hardware.

The success of Modular hinges on its ability to overcome the complexity of GPU programming,  addressing the "dark art" of mapping algorithms to GPUs and attracting a broader developer base beyond the current limited expertise.

title: 'High-markup' hospitals charge more but have significantly worse patient outcomes, study reveals
author: Medical Xpress – Health
essence: News Summary: A UCLA study published in JAMA Surgery found that US hospitals with the highest markups—up to 17 times the cost of care—had significantly worse patient outcomes (45% higher complication rates, 33% higher readmission rates) than lower-markup hospitals. Novelty/Claim to Fame: The study directly links hospital pricing data to patient outcomes, demonstrating that higher prices do not correlate with better care, and in fact, often result in poorer quality. Evidence/Uncertainty: The study analyzed data from the 2022 Nationwide Readmissions Database (NRD) on nearly 2000 hospitals and 362,400 patients undergoing four major elective surgeries.
reactions: World Impact:  The study reveals a significant disparity in US healthcare, where high-markup hospitals, predominantly for-profit and located in large metropolitan areas, charge exorbitant prices while delivering demonstrably worse patient outcomes, impacting patients, insurers, and taxpayers alike.

What could change next (speculation):  Increased public reporting of hospital markups linked to patient outcomes, coupled with potential regulatory changes at the state or federal level, could promote greater price transparency and accountability in the healthcare system.

Practical implication for readers:  Patients should advocate for greater price transparency and consider factors beyond cost when choosing healthcare providers, recognizing that higher prices do not guarantee better quality of care.

title: WA ‘ready to fight’ to keep contentious $60bn GST deal as Chalmers orders distribution review

Evidence/Uncertainty: The review, ordered by Treasurer Jim Chalmers in September 2025, will examine whether the post-2018 arrangements achieve "reasonable horizontal fiscal equalisation." reactions: The 2018 GST deal, costing an unexpectedly large $60bn over 11 years, is under review due to concerns that it disproportionately benefits Western Australia at the expense of other states and territories.

title: Diamonds reveal hidden chemistry deep inside Earth

essence: News Summary: Analysis of South African diamonds revealed nickel-rich metallic inclusions, providing the first direct evidence of predicted chemical reactions deep within Earth's mantle (280-470 km depth). Novelty/Claim to Fame: The discovery confirms long-standing theoretical models of mantle redox conditions and demonstrates how these reactions influence magma formation and diamond genesis. Evidence/Uncertainty: Nickel-iron alloys and nickel-rich carbonates were found within diamonds from the Voorspoed mine, along with coesite and other pressure indicators confirming depth (Yael Kempe, Yaakov Weiss et al., Nature Geoscience, 2025).
reactions: The discovery of nickel-rich metallic alloys within South African diamonds provides the first direct evidence of predicted mantle reactions at depths of 280-470 km, confirming long-standing models of Earth's mantle redox conditions.
Future research might focus on analyzing diamonds from different locations and depths to further refine models of mantle redox dynamics and their relationship to magma generation.

This research highlights the untapped potential of diamonds as "tiny time capsules" preserving information about deep Earth processes, offering valuable insights into mantle chemistry and the formation of volatile-rich magmas.

title: Longer body size means more female calves for baleen whale moms, contrary to popular hypothesis
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: A new study using over 100,000 baleen whale records refutes the Trivers-Willard hypothesis, showing that larger mothers are more likely to have female calves, not male. Novelty/Claim to Fame: The study contradicts the established Trivers-Willard hypothesis by demonstrating a positive correlation between maternal size and the likelihood of female offspring in baleen whales, a finding based on a large dataset of historical whaling records. Evidence/Uncertainty: The research analyzed data from over 100,000 baleen whales, spanning seven rorqual species, collected by Norwegian whalers from the early 1900s through the 1930s, showing a higher proportion of female calves born to larger mothers (e.g., 77% increase for humpbacks, 99% for sei whales).
reactions: This study, using a massive dataset from historical whaling records, challenges the Trivers-Willard hypothesis by demonstrating that larger baleen whale mothers are more likely to have female calves, suggesting that female reproductive success is more strongly linked to maternal size than previously thought.

Future research might explore the hormonal or genetic mechanisms underlying sex ratio adjustment in baleen whales, and investigate whether similar patterns exist in other marine mammal species or under different environmental conditions.

The finding that larger female baleen whales have a higher probability of producing female offspring highlights the importance of conserving whale populations and protecting their habitats to ensure the long-term reproductive success of these species.

title: Pest resistance threatens corn industry's newest biotech defense, study warns

title: Temperature-adaptive charging protocol could boost lithium battery lifespan for Mars exploration
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: A new temperature-adaptive charging protocol for lithium-Mars gas batteries (LMGBs) could significantly extend their lifespan, enabling continuous operation of Mars rovers. Novelty: The study reveals a temperature-dependent reaction mechanism in LMGBs, leading to a novel charging protocol that optimizes battery performance across Mars's temperature fluctuations. Evidence: Researchers at the University of Science and Technology of China (USTC) found that increasing temperature shifts the LMGB discharge reaction from a four-electron to a two-electron path, doubling reaction kinetics.
reactions: This research, published in Advanced Functional Materials, reveals a temperature-adaptive charging protocol that could significantly extend the lifespan of lithium-Mars gas batteries (LMGBs) for Mars exploration by manipulating reaction pathways and mitigating interface passivation.
Future research might focus on adapting this protocol to other extreme environments or exploring alternative battery chemistries with inherent temperature resilience.

title: Valley fever is spreading across the arid West, affecting people and dogs

reactions: ) Climate change is expanding the geographical range of the valley fever fungus, leading to increased incidence in areas previously unaffected, as evidenced by rising caseloads in California, Arizona, and potential spread to the Midwest.

reactions: This nanoscale selenium application to rice has the potential to significantly reduce the environmental impact of rice cultivation, decreasing greenhouse gas emissions and fertilizer runoff, while simultaneously boosting yields and nutritional value for a staple crop feeding billions.

title: Ancient pottery discovery unlocks earliest proof of horses in Bronze Age Sicily
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: Analysis of pottery fragments from a Sicilian site (near Polizzello mountain) dating to the early Bronze Age (third millennium B.C.) provides the earliest known evidence of horse presence and consumption in Sicily, predating previous estimates by approximately 1000 years. Novelty: The discovery pushes back the timeline of horse introduction to Sicily by a millennium, significantly altering understandings of Bronze Age Sicilian diet, culture, and interactions with other Mediterranean societies. Evidence: Davide Tanasi's team, using proteomic analysis in 2024 on pottery excavated in 2005, identified equine serum albumin (horse blood protein) on numerous vessels.
reactions: This discovery pushes back the timeline of horse presence and consumption in Sicily by a millennium, significantly altering understandings of Bronze Age diets, intercultural interactions, and ritual practices in the central Mediterranean.

Future research might focus on expanding the geographic scope of similar investigations to determine the extent of horse use across the Mediterranean during the Early Bronze Age, potentially revealing wider trade networks or migration patterns.

reactions: This research significantly advances our understanding of kimberlite eruptions, revealing the crucial role of CO2 in their ascent and the transportation of diamonds to the Earth's surface, a process previously poorly understood.

title: Fish oil supplements may not work for certain cancer patients
author: Medical Xpress – Health
essence: News Summary: A University of Michigan study found that the effectiveness of fish oil supplements in preventing colorectal cancer depends on the presence of the ALOX15 gene, suggesting that supplements may be ineffective for some patients. Novelty/Claim: The study reveals that the efficacy of EPA and DHA in suppressing colorectal cancer hinges on the presence of the ALOX15 enzyme, challenging the general assumption of their cancer-preventative benefits. Evidence/Uncertainty: Research in mice (University of Michigan and University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center) showed that fish oil increased colon tumors in ALOX15-deficient mice, while reducing them in ALOX15-positive mice.
reactions: The study's finding that fish oil's effectiveness against colorectal cancer depends on the presence of the ALOX15 enzyme suggests a significant limitation to its widespread use as a preventative measure.
Future research may focus on developing drugs to increase ALOX15 expression in cancer cells, thus potentially enhancing the efficacy of EPA and DHA supplementation.
Individuals considering fish oil supplements for cancer prevention should consult their physician to assess their ALOX15 status and determine the appropriateness of such supplementation.

title: EU proposes new delay to anti-deforestation rules

The postponement requires approval from member states and the European Parliament.

title: Engineers develop a magnetic transistor for more energy-efficient electronics

It also integrates memory functionality.
reactions: World Impact: This new magnetic transistor, utilizing chromium sulfur bromide, could significantly reduce energy consumption in electronics by enabling smaller, faster, and more energy-efficient circuits, as its magnetism allows for more efficient control of electricity flow and built-in memory functionality.

What could change next (speculation):  Future research might focus on scaling up the production of these transistors and exploring alternative magnetic semiconductor materials to further improve performance and reduce costs.

Practical implication for readers:  This development suggests that future electronic devices could be substantially smaller, faster, and more energy-efficient, potentially impacting the design and functionality of everything from smartphones to supercomputers.

title: The Need to Bake Out Silicone Based Thermal Control Coatings
author: NASA Breaking News
essence: News summary: Pre-baking ZnO-silicone thermal control coatings significantly reduces UV-induced degradation and improves long-term performance in space applications. Novelty/Claim: A pre-bake process for ZnO-silicone paints minimizes absorptivity changes caused by UV exposure, extending the lifespan of spacecraft thermal control systems. Evidence/Uncertainty: Baking S-31 paint at 260°C for 1 hour before 1780 equivalent solar hours (ESH) of UV exposure reduced absorptivity change from 0.02 to 0.006.
reactions: Pre-baking ZnO-silicone thermal control coatings significantly reduces UV-induced degradation and improves long-term performance in space, as evidenced by reduced absorptivity changes in both lab and MISSE experiments.
Further research could investigate the optimal bake-out temperature and duration for different ZnO-silicone formulations to maximize performance and minimize processing time.

Spacecraft designers and manufacturers should consider incorporating pre-bake procedures for ZnO-silicone thermal control coatings to ensure the long-term stability and effectiveness of their thermal control systems.

title: 'Nightmare bacteria' cases are increasing in the US
author: Medical Xpress – Health
essence: News Summary: A new CDC report reveals a nearly 70% increase in drug-resistant "nightmare bacteria" infections in the US between 2019 and 2023, driven primarily by bacteria containing the NDM gene. Novelty/Claim to Fame: The study highlights a dramatic surge in NDM-gene carrying bacteria, previously considered rare, indicating a significant public health threat. Evidence/Uncertainty: The rate of carbapenem-resistant infections rose from under 2 per 100,000 people in 2019 to over 3 per 100,000 in 2023, while NDM cases increased 460% during the same period.
reactions: World Impact: The rise of NDM-producing carbapenem-resistant Enterobacterales in the US, increasing by over 460% between 2019 and 2023, signals a significant threat to global health due to the limited treatment options and potential for community spread.

What could change next (speculation):  Increased antibiotic stewardship programs and improved surveillance, particularly in states currently lacking robust testing and reporting, could help to mitigate the spread of these drug-resistant bacteria, though the impact of the increased antibiotic use during the COVID-19 pandemic may continue to affect resistance patterns.

Practical implication for readers:  Routine infections, previously easily treatable, may become chronic and difficult to manage, highlighting the urgent need for responsible antibiotic use and enhanced public health measures to combat antimicrobial resistance.

title: Discovery expands understanding of Neolithic agricultural practices and diets in East Asia
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: Charred adzuki bean remains, dating back 9,000–8,000 years, were discovered in Xiaogao, China, pushing back the known cultivation of this legume in the Yellow River region by at least 4,000 years. Novelty/Claim to Fame: The discovery significantly extends the timeline of adzuki bean cultivation in East Asia, revealing its role in early Neolithic agricultural systems and highlighting regional variations in its use. Evidence/Uncertainty: Charred adzuki beans were found at the Xiaogao site (Shandong, China), dated to 9,000–8,000 years ago (published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Sept 22, 2025).
reactions: The discovery pushes back the known cultivation of adzuki beans in East Asia by 4,000 years, challenging the notion of singular geographical centers for plant domestication and supporting the idea of parallel developments across the region.
Future research might investigate the genetic diversity of adzuki beans across these regions to further clarify the pathways of domestication and migration.
This research highlights the importance of considering diverse culinary and dietary practices alongside environmental factors in understanding the complex process of plant domestication.

title: The Secret Service seized a network capable of shutting down New York City's cell service
author: Engadget
essence: News Summary: The Secret Service seized a large-scale network capable of disrupting New York City's cell service, including jamming cell towers and enabling encrypted communications, preventing a potential attack during the UN General Assembly. Novelty/Claim to Fame: The seizure represents a significant disruption of a sophisticated telecommunications cyber-operation with the potential to significantly impact communication across a major metropolitan area. Evidence/Uncertainty: The network comprised over 300 SIM servers and 100,000 SIM cards, and could send 30 million anonymous text messages per minute, according to a Secret Service official quoted in The New York Times.
reactions: World Impact:  The seizure of a network capable of disrupting New York City's cell service highlights the potential for large-scale telecommunications disruption and the need for enhanced cybersecurity measures, particularly around major international events.

What could change next (speculation):  Future attacks might target other critical infrastructure sectors or employ more sophisticated techniques to evade detection, necessitating a continuous evolution of defensive strategies.

title: Key mutation for later flowering of barley discovered
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: Researchers identified a gene mutation (PPD-H1 SNP22) in barley that causes later flowering, leading to higher yields in long-day regions, and its origin was traced to domesticated barley in the Southern Levant. Novelty/Claim to Fame: The study pinpoints the specific genetic mutation responsible for late flowering in barley and refutes previous assumptions about its origin. Evidence/Uncertainty: The study analyzed over 2,000 barley plants (940 wild, 1110 domesticated Hordeum vulgare) and a 6,000-year-old barley sample from Yoram Cave, Israel.
reactions: World Impact: The discovery of the PPD-H1 SNP22 mutation in barley, enabling later flowering and higher yields in long-day regions, could significantly improve barley production in northern latitudes.
What could change next: Further research might identify similar mutations in other cereal crops, leading to the development of higher-yielding varieties adapted to diverse climates.
Practical implication for readers: This research highlights the potential of genetic analysis to improve crop yields and enhance food security, especially in regions with changing climates.

title: Artificial plant device purifies radioactive soil with sunlight alone
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: A solar-powered artificial plant device, developed by a team at the Daegu Gyeongbuk Institute of Science and Technology (DGIST), efficiently removes radioactive cesium from contaminated soil. Novelty: The device offers a significantly faster and more cost-effective method for soil remediation compared to traditional methods, using only sunlight and requiring no additional water or electricity. Evidence: The device reduced cesium concentration by over 95% within 20 days in experimental trials, a process that typically takes months.
reactions: World Impact: This solar-powered artificial plant device offers a potentially transformative solution for remediating radioactive cesium contamination in soil, a problem previously lacking effective solutions, as highlighted by the significant challenges following the Fukushima disaster.

What could change next (speculation):  Further research might focus on adapting this technology to remediate other types of radioactive soil contamination or exploring its scalability for large-scale environmental cleanup projects.

Practical implication for readers: The development suggests a cost-effective and environmentally friendly approach to soil decontamination, particularly relevant in areas affected by nuclear accidents or legacy radioactive waste.

title: Darfur cholera cases rising at an 'alarming' rate as death toll in Sudan tops 3,000, says WHO
author: Medical Xpress – Health

Evidence/Uncertainty: As of Sunday, September 21, 2025, 12,739 cholera cases and 358 deaths were reported in over half of Darfur's localities; nationwide, over 113,600 cases and more than 3,000 deaths have been reported since July 2024, resulting in a fatality rate of 2.7%.
reactions: The ongoing Sudanese civil war has exacerbated a cholera outbreak, resulting in over 3,000 deaths nationwide and a sharply rising case count in Darfur, exceeding the WHO's 1% fatality target threshold.
Continued conflict and displacement in Sudan, coupled with limited access to clean water and healthcare, may lead to further escalation of the cholera outbreak and spread to other regions.
The alarming cholera situation in Darfur highlights the urgent need for increased humanitarian aid, improved sanitation infrastructure, and vaccination campaigns to mitigate the crisis.

reactions: New Zealand's stricter gun laws, particularly those implemented after the 1990 Aramoana and 2019 Christchurch shootings, have been associated with a significant reduction in firearm-related suicides and a demonstrable decrease in overall gun-related deaths and hospitalizations, as shown by a University of Otago study.

title: DHS Has Been Collecting US Citizens’ DNA for Years

reactions: World Impact: The Department of Homeland Security's collection of US citizens' DNA, exceeding 2.6 million profiles since 2020 and potentially reaching one-third of the CODIS database by 2034, represents a massive expansion of genetic surveillance with implications for global privacy norms.

title: AI model automates detection of developmental abnormalities in zebrafish embryos
author: Phys.org

Evidence: The model achieved 98% accuracy in identifying fertilized embryos and 92% accuracy in detecting abnormalities caused by 3,4-dichloroaniline, using a dataset of over 185,000 images (130,368 for fertility, 55,296 for toxicity) across 8-hour and 48-hour sequences respectively.
reactions: World Impact:  The AI model's high accuracy in detecting developmental abnormalities in zebrafish embryos could significantly accelerate drug screening processes and improve the safety and efficiency of drug development.

reactions: ) World Impact: This new catalyst significantly accelerates plastic upcycling into liquid fuels, offering a faster, more efficient, and environmentally friendly solution to plastic waste compared to traditional methods.

title: The shocking reason Arctic rivers are turning rusty orange
author: ScienceDaily

title: Beneath 300 kilometers: Scientists find first natural evidence of nickel-rich alloys deep in mantle

reactions: World Impact: The discovery of nickel-rich alloys in deep mantle diamonds provides the first natural confirmation of theoretical models, offering insights into mantle redox dynamics and the formation of volatile-rich magmas that shape continents.

title: Why alcohol blocks the liver from healing, even after you quit

reactions: Alcohol's damage to the liver extends beyond direct cellular injury; it creates a persistent inflammatory state that prevents proper cell regeneration, even after cessation of alcohol consumption, leading to roughly 3 million deaths annually worldwide.

The discovery of disrupted RNA splicing as a key mechanism in alcohol-related liver damage suggests potential new diagnostic markers (misspliced RNAs) and therapeutic targets for treating this deadly disease.

reactions: Current national plans for fossil fuel extraction are exceeding the remaining "carbon budget," jeopardizing the 1.5C climate threshold.

title: Science journalists as brokers of trust
author: Phys.org

Evidence/Uncertainty: The research, published in the Journal of Science Communication (2025) by ITAS (Karlsruhe Institute of Technology), involved 87 participants (mostly journalists) from Germany, Italy, and Lithuania.
reactions: A study across Germany, Italy, and Lithuania reveals that science journalists view themselves as "knowledge brokers," actively negotiating trust with audiences rather than simply reporting facts, contradicting the common narrative of collapsing trust in science.

The increasing influence of online platforms and the pressure for clicks may lead to a further decline in in-depth science reporting, favoring sensationalized narratives and potentially exacerbating the spread of misinformation.

Readers should critically evaluate news sources, considering the context and potential biases inherent in the media ecosystem, and support initiatives that promote well-funded, independent science journalism.

reactions: World Impact:  The Canadian study demonstrates that expanding virtual care alone is insufficient to overcome geographical barriers to specialist access for rural populations, contradicting widespread assumptions about its potential to bridge the healthcare gap.

What could change next (speculation): Future interventions might focus on centralized referral systems to connect rural patients with distant specialists and address provider referral patterns that favor local networks.

Practical implication for readers:  Policymakers and healthcare providers should consider strategies beyond simply increasing virtual care availability, such as addressing referral practices and patient preferences, to improve rural access to specialists.

title: Ordinary ice found to have shocking electrical powers
author: ScienceDaily

Novelty: This finding challenges prior understanding of ice's electrical properties, potentially explaining lightning formation and enabling new ice-based technologies. Evidence: The study, published in Nature Physics in September 2025, involved researchers from ICN2 (Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona), Xi'an Jiaotong University, and Stony Brook University.
reactions: The discovery that ice exhibits flexoelectricity and, at low temperatures, ferroelectricity could revolutionize our understanding of atmospheric electricity generation and potentially lead to new energy harvesting technologies, as suggested by the researchers' connection of these properties to lightning formation.

Future research might explore the potential for ice-based energy storage devices or sensors operating in extremely cold environments, building on the finding that ice's electrical properties are comparable to those of electroceramic materials currently used in advanced technologies.

This research suggests that seemingly simple materials like ice can possess surprising and technologically relevant properties, highlighting the potential for further discovery through continued investigation of common substances.

title: Reversing Antarctic sea ice loss depends on ocean layering, study finds
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: A new study finds that the recovery of Antarctic sea ice depends not only on CO2 emissions but critically on the stratification of the Southern Ocean, with strong stratification hindering ice recovery even under reduced emissions. reactions: Ants utilize a novel genetic mechanism—transcriptional interference—to ensure each olfactory neuron expresses only one odorant receptor, maintaining the clarity of their sense of smell. title: Hybridization of interlayer excitons in bilayer semiconductor hints at many-body state
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: Researchers at Harvard University and other institutions observed unusual hybridization of interlayer excitons in bilayer molybdenum disulfide (MoS₂), potentially indicating a previously unobserved many-body quantum state. Novelty/Claim to Fame: The study provides indirect experimental evidence of interlayer electron coherence in a bilayer semiconductor at temperatures as high as 75K, a significant achievement in the field. Evidence/Uncertainty: The team observed "stochastic anti-crossing" in reflectance spectra of doped MoS₂ using an optical technique involving broadband white light illumination and gate voltage tuning (Liu et al., Nature Physics, 2025; DOI: 10.1038/s41567-025-02971-0).
reactions: The observed hybridization of interlayer excitons in bilayer MoS₂ provides indirect experimental evidence for a theorized many-body state, potentially paving the way for advancements in optoelectronic and quantum technologies.
Future research may explore similar hybridization in trilayer materials and investigate methods to achieve fully coherent, rather than stochastic, hybridization through layer twisting.

This research highlights the potential of manipulating interlayer excitons in bilayer semiconductors to achieve novel quantum states, opening avenues for developing advanced electronic and optoelectronic devices.

title: El Niño brings more intense rain to India's wettest regions
author: Phys.org
essence: News Summary: A new study reveals that El Niño intensifies daily rainfall in India's wettest regions, contrary to the previously held belief that it reduces overall monsoon rainfall. Novelty/Claim to Fame: The research demonstrates a previously unrecognized link between El Niño and increased intensity of daily rainfall in specific Indian regions, improving the potential for forecasting extreme weather events. Evidence/Uncertainty: The study, published in Science (DOI: 10.1126/science.adg5577) in September 2025, analyzed daily rainfall data from 1901-2020, finding a 43% increase in the chance of very heavy downpours (over 250 mm) across India during El Niño years, rising to 59% in the Central Monsoon Zone.
reactions: ) El Niño's impact on India's monsoon season is more nuanced than previously understood, increasing the likelihood of extremely intense rainfall in already wet regions while decreasing it in drier areas.

) Future research might investigate the specific regional variations in the impact of El Niño intensity on rainfall extremes and explore the potential for improved forecasting models incorporating other climate factors.
)  Improved El Niño-based forecasting of extreme rainfall events can allow for better flood mitigation strategies and resource allocation in India's monsoon-affected regions.

Evidence: The whistle, found in 2008 but only recently identified, originated from a juvenile cow's toe bone and was discovered in a building near a royal cemetery in Stone Village, Akhetaten (modern-day Amarna).
reactions: ) The discovery of a 3,300-year-old cow bone whistle in Akhetaten sheds light on the methods of policing used in ancient Egypt to control workers at royal cemeteries.

title: Distillation Can Make AI Models Smaller and Cheaper
author: WIRED
essence: News Summary: Knowledge distillation, a decade-old AI technique for creating smaller, cheaper models by training a "student" model on a larger "teacher" model, is gaining prominence despite not being a recent breakthrough. Novelty/Claim to Fame: DeepSeek's R1 chatbot, while seemingly innovative due to its low cost and high performance, leveraged the well-established technique of knowledge distillation, raising questions about the originality of their achievement. Evidence/Uncertainty: The technique originated in a 2015 Google paper co-authored by Geoffrey Hinton; Google's DistilBERT (2019) is a successful example; the arxiv.org preprint on distillation has over 25,000 citations.
reactions: ) Distillation's impact is significant, enabling smaller, cheaper AI models, as evidenced by DeepSeek's R1 chatbot rivaling leading models while using a fraction of the resources, causing significant stock market fluctuations.

)  Future developments may involve refining distillation techniques for even greater efficiency and exploring its application to increasingly complex AI tasks like chain-of-thought reasoning, as demonstrated by the NovaSky lab's success with Sky-T1.

) Readers should understand that distillation, while widely used and seemingly simple, requires access to the "teacher" model's internal workings, raising concerns about potential misuse and intellectual property issues, as illustrated by allegations against DeepSeek.

title: Smoking’s hidden gut bacteria trick may lead to new colitis treatments
author: ScienceDaily

reactions: This research reveals a previously unknown mechanism by which smoking affects inflammatory bowel diseases, showing that smoking-produced metabolites enable mouth bacteria to colonize the gut, impacting immune responses differently in Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

Future research might focus on identifying specific strains of Streptococcus mitis most effective in treating ulcerative colitis and developing targeted therapies using hydroquinone or similar metabolites to safely replicate the beneficial effects observed in smokers.

The discovery suggests potential for novel ulcerative colitis treatments using probiotics or metabolite-based therapies, offering a safer alternative to smoking while addressing the underlying gut microbial imbalance.

title: Deprecation of Node 20 on GitHub Actions runners
author: GitHub Changelog
essence: News summary: GitHub Actions is deprecating Node.js version 20 on its runners, transitioning to Node.js 24 as the default by March 4, 2026. Novelty/Claim for fame: This change updates the default Node.js version on GitHub Actions runners, improving compatibility and security. Evidence/Uncertainty: Node.js 20 will reach end-of-life in April 2026.
reactions: This deprecation of Node.js 20 on GitHub Actions runners will necessitate updates to numerous workflows and actions, potentially impacting the functionality of countless projects relying on older Node versions.

Given the incompatibility of Node 24 with older macOS versions and ARM32 architectures, we can expect further adjustments to GitHub Actions' infrastructure and potentially increased support requests from users needing to migrate.
GitHub Actions users should proactively update their workflows to utilize Node 24 or set the appropriate environment variables to avoid disruptions after March 4th, 2026, and maintain compatibility.
